body:
Agreed on all counts, @p. The cases in which a humans.txt is a great idea are not entirely obvious, and absolutely not universal.

On Aug 30, 2011, at 9:01 PM, p wrote:

> Is the goal here to provide a sample file or plug rails and/or the core team more?
> 
>> More often than not, the owners of the site don't like the authors signing it; they claim that doing so may make the site less efficient. By adding a txt file, you can prove your authorship (not your property) in an external, fast, easy and accessible way.
> 
> Assuming owners of a site indeed don't like the authors signing it (what does "less efficient" mean?), what do you think will happen when they discover that the authors signed it anyway in this semi-stealthy way?
> 
> If you are a developer you can trivially embed your name via html comments on the main page or on all pages.
> 
> For personal sites this humans.txt idea seems pointless - put everything on your about page and let everyone see it. For business sites doing this is asking for trouble. Looking at google's humans.txt, they don't have any names there. How is it different from their corporate about page? (The google's one is actually entirely useless. "Google is built by a large team of engineers, ..." - really? I would never have guessed.)
> 
> I also found the following interesting:
> 
>> humans.txt is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License
> 
> This is an incredibly restrictive license for something being promoted as any sort of a standard.
>
